title.value: Improving day-ahead Solar Irradiance Time Series Forecasting by Leveraging Spatio-Temporal Context
title.justification: This is the title provided at the start of the document, including the subtitle that explains the main contribution.
title.quote: Improving day-ahead Solar Irradiance Time Series Forecasting by Leveraging Spatio-Temporal Context

description: This paper proposes a deep learning architecture called CrossViViT for leveraging spatio-temporal context using satellite data to achieve highly accurate day-ahead time-series forecasting of Global Horizontal Irradiance (GHI). It also introduces a novel multi-modal dataset that combines satellite imagery with solar irradiance and other physical variables.

type.justification: The paper presents a new deep learning architecture and evaluates its performance using a novel dataset, thus focusing on experimental results and empirical validation.
type.quote: In this paper, we put forth a deep learning architecture designed to harness spatio-temporal context using satellite data, to attain highly accurate day-ahead time-series forecasting for any given station, with a particular emphasis on forecasting Global Horizontal Irradiance (GHI).

sub_research_fields.justification: The primary focus is on enhancing the accuracy of time-series forecasting for solar irradiance by using a deep learning model.
sub_research_fields.quote: We present a deep learning architecture called CrossViViT, designed to leverage spatiotemporal context (such as satellite data) in order to achieve highly accurate medium-term (1 day horizon) time-series forecasting at any given station.

name.justification: AutoFormer is one of the models used for benchmarking in the experiments.
name.quote: AutoFormer (Wu et al., 2021)

caracteristics.justification: AutoFormer applies decomposed transformers for long-term series forecasting.

name.justification: CrossFormer is evaluated as a baseline for comparison in the study.
name.quote: CrossFormer (Zhang and Yan, 2023)

caracteristics.justification: CrossFormer employs cross-dimensional dependency in transformer-based time-series forecasting.

name.justification: It is the main model introduced and experimentally validated in this paper.
name.quote: We present a deep learning architecture called CrossViViT, designed to leverage spatiotemporal context (such as satellite data) in order to achieve highly accurate medium-term (1 day horizon) time-series forecasting at any given station.

caracteristics.justification: The model is specifically developed for leveraging spatio-temporal context using satellite data for time-series forecasting.
caracteristics.quote: Our approach aims to integrate the available historical time-series data with video clips of spatio-temporal physical context to enhance the prediction of future time series for solar irradiance.

name.justification: DLinear is included in the comparison of different forecasting models used in the study.
name.quote: DLinear (Zeng et al., 2022)

caracteristics.justification: DLinear is a model specifically designed for time series forecasting, leveraging linear structures.

name.justification: FEDFormer is mentioned among the various models evaluated for their performance.
name.quote: FEDFormer (Zhou et al., 2022a)

caracteristics.justification: FEDFormer is designed for series forecasting, enhancing transformer models with frequency decomposition.

name.justification: FiLM is included as a comparative model in the study's benchmarks.
name.quote: FiLM (Zhou et al., 2022b)

caracteristics.justification: FiLM is a model structure that utilizes feature-wise linear modulation, suitable for time series forecasting.

name.justification: Informer is used as a baseline model for comparison in the experiments.
name.quote: Informer (Zhou et al., 2021)

caracteristics.justification: Informer is another Transformer-based model designed for long sequence time-series forecasting.

name.justification: LightTS is used as one of the baseline models in the experimental comparisons.
name.quote: LighTS (Zhang et al., 2022)

caracteristics.justification: LightTS is a lightweight model for time series forecasting, mainly using MLP structures.

name.justification: This is an alternative version of the CrossViViT model that allows extracting uncertainty estimations for predictions.
name.quote: We present a Multi-Quantile version of the model which allows to extract uncertainty estimation attached to each prediction.

caracteristics.justification: The model extends the CrossViViT architecture by including multiple MLP heads dedicated to predicting specific quantiles for uncertainty estimation.
caracteristics.quote: To obtain prediction intervals for each forecasted value, we propose a methodology which can be used for any deep learning forecasting model, here resulting in an alternative version of the CrossViViT architecture.

name.justification: PatchTST is listed among various models for comparative performance evaluation.
name.quote: PatchTST (Nie et al., 2023)

caracteristics.justification: PatchTST uses transformer-based architecture which is evident from its name and the context of its usage in the paper.

name.justification: Reformer is mentioned as one of the comparative models evaluated against CrossViViT in the experimental section.
name.quote: ReFormer (Kitaev et al., 2020)

caracteristics.justification: Reformer is a variant of the Transformer architecture optimized for efficiency and is used as a benchmark.

name.justification: Time-series measurements from the Baseline Surface Radiation Network (BSRN) datasets are used in the experiments.
name.quote: The time-series measurements were obtained from Baseline Surface Radiation Network datasets (Driemel et al., 2018).

name.justification: Cener station is listed as a source of measurement data used in this research.

name.justification: The paper utilizes satellite data from the EUMETSAT RSS dataset to provide spatio-temporal context.
name.quote: In this study, we utilize the EUMETSAT Rapid Scan Service (RSS) dataset (Holmlund, 2003), which spans a period of 15 years from 2008 to 2022, with an original resolution of 5 minutes, later aligned with the time series data.

name.justification: Izana is one of the stations used for gathering time series measurements in the study.

name.justification: The library is used for computing optical flow in the satellite images.
name.quote: We computed the optical flow for each channel using the TVL1 algorithm (Sánchez Pérez et al., 2013) from the OpenCV package (Bradski, 2000).

name.justification: Used for calculating the zenith angle of the sun, which is necessary for computing Global Horizontal Irradiance (GHI) from the BSRN dataset.
name.quote: The GHI component was computed using the formula: GHI = DN I × cos z + DHI where z is the zenith angle of the sun obtained from the pvlib python library (Holmgren et al., 2020).
